name: yore
etymology: Middle English, from yore, adverb, long ago, from Old English gēara, from gēar year year

information.definition: of long ago or former times (used in nostalgic or mock-nostalgic recollection).
information.example: a great empire in days of yore

mnemonic: 1. fortnight sounds like fouteen night so fourteen days,.,,ie.,two weeks
name: fortnight
etymology: Middle English fourtenight, alteration of fourtene night, from Old English fēowertȳne niht fourteen nights

information.definition: a period of two weeks.

name: jubilee
etymology: Middle English, from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French jubilé, from Late Latin jubilaeus, modification of Late Greek iōbēlaios, from Hebrew yōbhēl ram's horn, jubilee

information.definition: Judaism
a special anniversary of an event, especially one celebrating twenty-five or fifty years of a reign or activity.
information.example: to celebrate its jubilee, the club is holding a tournament

name: advent
mnemonic:

"went" is the past tense of go."ad vent" is opposite of "go" which is "come".(ie) "arrival".

3. "ad"+"vent" ad went  and cinema or soap "arrives"

4. Advent = Ad(add) + vent ( air/empty)= Fill up the empty Seats in fuction means Arrive

5. advent -> added event -> awaiting event...

6. ad(toward)+vent(vent)=arrival

7. when u go for ADVENTure there will be no arrival  2 home

8. Starting four weeks before Christmas the arrival of Jesus is celebrated each weekend as 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Advent.

9. It's an event but it's added so awaited event

10. Advent= ADD + INvent

etymology: Middle English, from Medieval Latin adventus, from Latin, arrival, from advenire

information.definition: the first season of the Church year, leading up to Christmas and including the four preceding Sundays.
the arrival of a notable person or thing.
information.example: the advent of television

name: epoch
etymology: Medieval Latin epocha, from Greek epochē cessation, fixed point, from epechein to pause, hold back, from epi- + echein to hold scheme
pronunciation: ˈe-pək, ˈe-ˌpäk, US also & British usually ˈē-ˌpäk

information.definition: a particular period of time in history or a person's life.
information.example: the Victorian epoch

information.definition: occurring twice a year.
information.example: the biannual meeting of the planning committee

name: era
etymology: Late Latin aera, from Latin, counters, plural of aer-, aes copper, money ore

information.definition: a long and distinct period of history.
information.example: his death marked the end of an era

information.definition: each of the aspects of the moon or a planet, according to the amount of its illumination, especially the new moon, the first quarter, the full moon, and the last quarter.
information.example: the phases of the moon

information.definition: carry out (something) in gradual stages.
information.example: the work is being phased over a number of years

information.definition: a distinct period or stage in a process of change or forming part of something's development.
information.example: the final phases of the war

name: perennial
etymology: Latin perennis, from per- throughout + annus year per-, annual

information.definition: lasting or existing for a long or apparently infinite time; enduring or continually recurring.
information.example: his perennial distrust of the media

information.definition: (of a plant) living for several years.
information.example: cow parsley is perennial

name: contemporaneous
etymology: Latin contemporaneus, from com- + tempor-, tempus time

information.definition: existing at or occurring in the same period of time.
information.example: Pythagoras was contemporaneous with Buddha

name: coeval
etymology: Latin coaevus, from co- + aevum age, lifetime aye

information.definition: having the same age or date of origin; contemporary.
information.example: these lavas were coeval with the volcanic activity

name: eternal
etymology: Middle English, from Middle French, from Late Latin aeternalis, from Latin aeternus eternal, from aevum age, eternity aye

information.definition: lasting or existing forever; without end.
information.example: the secret of eternal youth

information.definition: used to emphasize expressions of admiration, gratitude, etc.
information.example: to his eternal credit, he maintained his dignity throughout

information.definition: used to refer to an everlasting or universal spirit, as represented by God.
information.example: a man entirely under the sway of the Eternal and not of the material

mnemonic:

2. Enn means year Therefore, Biennial - Happening every second year Perennial - continuing from year to year, present at all seasons.

3. BI-ANNUAL

4. Enn means year
Therefore, +BI MEANS TWO..

Biennial - Happening every second year

Perennial - continuing from year to year, present at all seasons.

name: biennial

information.definition: taking place every other year.
information.example: the first of a series of biennial exhibitions

name: perpetual
etymology: Middle English perpetuel, from Anglo-French, from Latin perpetuus uninterrupted, from per- through + petere to go to feather

information.definition: never ending or changing.
information.example: deep caves in perpetual darkness

information.definition: occurring repeatedly; so frequent as to seem endless and uninterrupted.
information.example: their perpetual money worries

information.definition: (of a plant) blooming or fruiting several times in one season.
information.example: he grows perpetual flowering carnations

name: halcyon
etymology: Middle English alceon, from Latin halcyon, from Greek alkyōn, halkyōn

information.definition: a mythical bird said by ancient writers to breed in a nest floating at sea at the winter solstice, charming the wind and waves into calm.
denoting a period of time in the past that was idyllically happy and peaceful.
information.example: the halcyon days of the mid 1980s, when profits were soaring

name: millennium
etymology: New Latin, from Latin mille thousand + New Latin -ennium (as in biennium)

information.definition: a period of a thousand years, especially when calculated from the traditional date of the birth of Christ.
information.example: silver first came into use on a substantial scale during the 3rd millennium BC

information.definition: (of a record of events) following the order in which they occurred.
information.example: the entries are in chronological order

name: eon

information.definition: an indefinite and very long period of time.
information.example: he reached the crag aeons before I arrived

name: interval
etymology: Middle English intervalle, from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French entreval, from Latin intervallum space between ramparts, interval, from inter- + vallum rampart wall

information.definition: the difference in pitch between two sounds.
an intervening time.
information.example: after his departure, there was an interval of many years without any meetings

information.definition: a pause or break in activity.
information.example: an interval of mourning

information.definition: a space between two things; a gap.
information.example: the rapids have some short intervals of still water
